title: Billboard Charts Analysis
text:
# Identify top 5 artists by song count
top_artists <- charts %>%
  count(artist, sort = TRUE) %>%
  slice_max(n, n = 10) %>%
  pull(artist)

# Filter original data for those artists
charts %>%
  filter(artist %in% top_artists) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = rank, y = song)) +
  geom_bin2d(bins = 70) +
  scale_fill_viridis_c() +
  theme_bw()

title: About
text:
1 Introduction
On this site, an analysis of the Billboard charts was conducted using historical data.
The results of the study are presented through clear and informative graphs, highlighting trends and changes over time.


2 Methodology
The analysis followed these main steps:

Collecting Billboard chart data for a selected time period

Preprocessing the data (cleaning, normalization)

Visualizing the results using graphs



3 Results
The graphs below illustrate key findings of the analysis.
They help trace the evolution of musical preferences, as well as the popularity of different genres and artists over time.


4 Conclusion
This analysis provided valuable insights into the development of the music industry and listener preferences, based on Billboard chart data.

title: Billie Eilish: Interactive Chart Analysis
text:
library(plotly)
p3 <- ggplot(billie, aes(x = song, y = rank, fill = song)) +
  geom_boxplot(show.legend = FALSE) +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  labs(title = "Billie Eilish: Rank Distribution by Song",
       x = "Song", y = "Rank") +
  theme_minimal()

ggplotly(p3)
